Extreme heat and wildfires are the two climate emergencies that most effect Avenal State Prison. Avenal is in a region that naturally reaches extremely hot (95'-110' for weeks) temperatures in the summer. I personally do not handle the heat very well so it is an especially horrible experience for me. The housing units are equipped with swamp coolers which do not operate at 100% and frequently break down. The housing units are also equipped with two giant ceiling fans but unless you are standing directly beneath it, it is ineffectual at cooling the building overall. The dorms in the corner of the buildings constantly reach temperatures over 95', a 3 ft diameter floor fan is provided but only move the hot air around, it doesn't cool the dorm. When the building temp. reaches 95', the prison provides two 10 gal (approx.) "Igloo" containers of ice water once or twice a day. We used to be allowed to purchase small travel clocks with thermometers but CDCR has banned them because Inmates would continually file "602"'s for being housed in extreme heat conditions. CDCR doesn't want us to know the temperature because they do not want to be held accountable for the cruel and intolerable conditions they force us to live in. They also don't want to pay the money that is necessary to fix the problem.
 When it comes to wildfires, Avenal State Prison is positioned next to some grassy hills. Twice in 6 years these hills have caught on fire. I've never heard of any sort of emergency plan.

 COVID-19 Pandemic Experience 2/20/2023
 Extreme cold temperatures, extended periods, 3 pages.
 My name is [redacted]. I've been living at the Correctional Training Facility since Nov, 2015 to this present day. I would like to share my story during the COVID-19 pandemic. With-in the first week of January 2021 I experienced a headache, fever, and body aches for two days. Soon after, CTF were testing me and prison inmates for COVID-19, I tested positive for COVID-19. A few days later the correctional officer came to my door to inform me that I tested positive for COVID-19 and that I had to pack up my belongings onto a four wheeled cart. He told me to go to tent city located behind Mamoth Clinic, at that time it was called "The White Elephant." CTF hired an outside company to set up two tent Cities, one was located in the C yard. Another was located nearby the B yard, within the B yard perimeter. The outside company provided a main trailer power generator that later failed and was replaced by another main trailer power generator. They provided two separate trailers of private stall showers, and one trailer for hand washing stations. They also provided portable restrooms and several ground lighting systems to light up the areas throughout the whole city. They also provided fourteen eight man tents to accommodate inmates that tested positive. Also, one eight man tent to accommodate the correctional officers. Each tent had its own HVAC package systems. Some were strip heat & mechanical cooling, some were mechanical heat pump producing heating & cooling. I lived in the #8 tent for 10 days. The heating failed to keep us warm. A service man from Cobalt came out and failed to repair our system. I filed a formal complaint to the correctional officers and I was moved to another tent. That tent heating system failed to keep us warm. I asked around and every heating system failed to keep the inmates warm.
 After a week went by, a terrible storm came in and damaged the ground lighting, the high winds caused damage. The HVAC ducts, round spiral ducts on the ground level would be blown in such a way to prevent proper air flow from the package to ground level then up and connected to the tent itself. The storm lasted for several days. Raining, day and night for several days. The whole tent city was flooded with water over the mud. We ALL had to walk through the thick soft heavy mud to use the portable toilets outside our tents during the day and late at night it was very dangerous. I had to go to the boys room three to four times a night. I'm 65 years old at that time. It was very difficult for me. I had to clean my boots every time I returned to my tent. The temperature was in the very low 30' F and the heating systems were overwhelmed because the outside temperature was in the low 30'F. Several inmates were heating up water from their hot pots to try to defrost manually the ice off the condensing coil so they could get some heat from their heat pump. Many heat pumps failed to go into automatic defrost. I determined that the tent I was transferred to when the unit produced heat for 30 minutes, it would go into defrost for 10 to 15 min then it would reverse the cycle of refrigerant to produce another 30 minutes of heat then another 10 to 15 min to defrost. In the meantime whenever that system defrosts for that 10 to 15 minutes, it produced a lot of cold air in the tent. I'm a HVAC service technician for over 30 years. I don't think these systems accommodated a strip heat system that is activated when the heat pump is in defrost mode.
 In my opinion these HVAC package systems were not designed to work under very low outside ambient temperatures of 30'F. There are specialized systems to provide the necessary heat as needed when the outside temperature is very low. We needed a heating system that would provide temps of 76' to 80'F inside A TENT to accommodate eight men to keep warm. Please note: When I'm in my cell when the outside temperature is in the low 30's F my Ken-Tech fold up travel clock has a temperature indicator giving me my cell temperature when it is very cold outside. Including solid concrete walls, the temperature at this time and date, 2/20/2023 at 7:38 pm, it's a lovely 80'F in our cell. The temperature maintains usually 76' to 80' F, thank you CTF, you're the best. But fail to keep any prison inmate warm in a tent outside when it's 30'F with very high winds and SEVERAL DAYS AND NIGHTS OF RAIN. I also want to mention again the main trailer electric generator failed. I heard that the generator failed because it tripped a low oil safety control. The company didn't monitor the oil level in the electric generator compartment. Several Cobalt service technicians were called out because of the broken HVAC systems. Funny that they did fix the correctional officers heating (tent) system. Ella Baker, if there is any questions I could answer, feel free to contact me! I would be willing to help. I hope no one ever has to go through what many of us inmates went through ever again.
 Sincerely, [Redacted]
